author: timbeiko
content:
I feel like we almost need a beacon chain level for 1559 at this point with various versions. On one hand, there are a ton of good ideas that are being discussed and we'll definitely want to incorporate some of them in the final version, but on the other, using "vanilla 1559" will speed development up greatly for now, and probably still uncover some bugs. 

I'm not sure what's the best way to do this, but I'd be in favor of a sort of "spec freeze" (aside from bug fixes obviously) with what we have now (incl. the transition period, different tx types, etc.) and then in 1-2 months once we have more data about how 1559 is working, the various potential ideas and the outputs of some of the R&D work, we can do a major upgrade to a "v2". Curious what others think of this, and what the best way to do such a thing would be ðŸ¤”

author: sky.cactus
content:
I'm against a "spec freeze" for a few reasons:
1. I don't want to end up going to market with something that is sub par because we decided it was "too hard" to iterate.
2. I think iteration is critical in getting this right, which means getting things out there and testing them.
3. The engineering involved in 1559 is (IMO, engineer but not a client dev) not the long pole/bottleneck.
4. I think it is unlikely we'll see particularly interesting/useful data from integration testnets just because they don't represent the real world well enough.  Any useful insights we can likely get from private single-client testnets which should be able to iterate pretty easily/freely and can target whatever they want (no need to coordinate).

author: sky.cactus
content: 5. Once we figure out that we want to do X instead of Y, it *feels* like a waste of effort to continue working towards X.  For example, if a new client wants to add support for 1559 and join the integration testnet, they will have to first implement code that everyone knows is going to be dropped only to then excise that code later.  In the case of the current open changeset, that means writing complicated code (migration code) that will be deleted when we drop the migration code (assuming the proposal gets general agreement and merged, which so far is looking likely).
